Republicans activate their base by telling them that America, Western Civilization, and/or Christianity are on the line unless they vote and their side wins. The opposition is buying votes and engaging in election fraud and hates America and must be defeated by any means possible.

The base that believes this stuff turns out to vote for people who believe it too -- who believe that we must be saved from socialism now before it is too late. Thus fired up, they want to do something huge to turn the country around. They have been told again and again how liberals and the lamestream media use lies and fear to disable the majority, so when they hear their own leaders using the same sort of reasoning, they do not listen and instead grow even more determined. They have been taught to be suspicious of experts, whose opinions have been bought.

The Republicans made this bed for themselves, working long and hard on it, and now they must sleep there. They made their supporters resistant to common sense or evidence and very tolerant of inconsistency in the movement. They never discussed the various reason why Obama was bad, which were valid and which not, so they have lost the habit or ability or willingness to seek reality among the illusions.

These people will have to be isolated and ignored until they come to their senses. Bring back earmarks (the grease of political wheeling and dealing), but no earmarks for them.

One key driver of the so-called 'Kurtzian Republicanism' overlooked by Ross Douthat is the role of outsider funders-- including the infamous Koch Brothers-- in fomenting the support for government shutdown and debt ceiling default. The New York Times ran an excellent investigative piece on this subject on October 5-6. The point being that tremendous sums were spent to produce this dysfunctional result.

Douthat also predictably overlooks an honorable way out of this morass-- an alliance of Democrats and the few Republican moderates to pass a clean continuing resolution and debt ceiling increase. Of course, that would require courage, sound judgment, and civic responsibility, qualities in short supply in today's Republican Party, especially in its Tea Party faction.

Sigh. I don't understand why what I write is so often misinterpreted. The young lady who was acting irresponsibly and then crying about it was an ongoing psychotherapy client. I did not say, nor imply, that it was her first session with me.

And before people jump to more conclusions about this particular person, allow me to clarify that she is highly responsible about her grades and schoolwork, generally speaking, but suffers from the same, general sense of helplessness and an emotional over-reactivity I see in many people her age.

I imagine the next line of attack will be that people who come to psychotherapy are not a reflection of the population at large. I am in a position to comment on trends across time, given how long I've been in practice. The problems I comment and write about are relatively new, cropping up in the last 10 - 15 years.

Another method of getting open access to first-class material about retirement is a very versatile technology, one that requires no expensive platforms and, if accessed in the daytime, no electricity, even for light. It's called a "book."

Let me recommend one book in particular:
Taylor Larimore, Mel Lindauer, Richard A. Ferri, Laura F. Dogu, The Bogleheads' Guide to Retirement Planning, John Wiley and Sons, Hoboken, NJ, 2009.

By the way, the folks who say they never use their high school algebra forget that algebra class is where you learn about exponential functions and compound interest -- the essential topics to understand not only investment, but debt.
A little review before investing or borrowing would, no pun intended, really pay off.

The far Democratic left had and has valid perspectives if not the whole truth, about Vietnam, the decline of manufacturing, growth in income inequality, the business of American medicine, Iraq, predatory lending, the treatment of various minorities, the environment, and many other areas.  Many of these perspectives turned out to be true.  The far Republican right is equally unhappy with the status quo, but for very different reasons. Nicole,

I am absolutely an introvert. The world needs all sorts of people, and I know my kids won't necessarily have this trait. I'm a-ok with that.

But even extroverts need time to think, plan, create and practice.

I may be biased. I had a good friend growing up who was an extrovert and a highly scheduled busy-bee (sports, clubs, committees..), by her own choice. When we became teenagers, I found her to be rash in her decision making. She just didn't seem to think things through, and she kept getting into these scrapes. It baffled me. It went badly for her. I cannot put my finger exactly on what it was, but I think maybe she was a natural born do-er who just needed someone to put the brakes on, and expect her (and teach her) to be a good thinker too.

This is all about balance, and I agree that what is balanced for one kid will be completely off-kilter for another. But I think parents need to set the limits, because some kids will stay in their comfort zone all day if allowed, and some will charge full speed ahead unless reigned in.

People have a better life in Europe - free health care, free college education, and they seem to have longer vacations. In our country, people live in fear about keeping health care and college costs from ruining them, or how to ever get it. It seems that kids don't make that much money after all when they graduate. Lots are stuck in $10 an hour jobs. University and College hiring no longer leads to tenure in most cases. And if you look at the politicians we elect, our country is surely filled with awfully stupid people. We've become a country that only caters to the rich, or rather the super rich, and we know that they, just as with the nobility in times past, care nothing about those below them.

What on earth are you talking about! There are still some excellent public high schools out there. Many of them are STEM magnet schools where one must apply to get in. But they ARE public schools financed by tax dollars.

The biggest problem with all our public schools is administrations that spend more time worrying about some sort of racial/economic balance, often achieved by expensive busing, than on a rigorous curriculum and individual evaluations. For the first time this year, my 5th grade grandson is in an all-advanced program class. He's so much happier being to move more quickly through the curriculum and not be distracted by lower-performing students, many of whom have behavior problems. But his school is loath to even admit such a class exists.

You cannot tell me that those lower performing students are not happier in a class if their peers. They will get the time they need to learn new concepts and not be embarrassed when others get it more quickly. But that's not PC today.

There are some great schools out there for bright, motivated students. I do worry about those who get little support from parents.

What we need to do is bring back the technical high schools. We still need plumbers, electricians and car mechanics and they can make a living wage doing these trades. College is not for everyone.

But shutting down the government in order to defund Obamacare was a strategy based around a sound bite. It was superficial because to get into the details would have meant losing that part of their base that benefits from aspects of Obamacare, like covering pre-existing conditions.

When you look at the Republican misestimates in the recent election and now these muddled moves, it looks like they are going through a mass delusion. Unfortunately, the rest of us are suffering.

In our current discussion, many make the assumption that the problem only exists when governments do the paying; if the government were out of the picture, people would simply buy the health care they needed, or as much of it as they could afford.

In the best of all possible worlds, I would agree with the recommendation that Boehner construct an alliance of Democrats and moderate Republicans to end this crisis. It's the right thing to do and offers the soundest possible policy outcome.

The unfortunate outcome, however, is that Boehner would lose his Speakership to Eric Cantor, the Majority Leader. And while Boehner has been difficult to deal with, I suspect that Cantor would be materially worse.

The best resolution that I can see is a brokered compromise between Mitch McConnell and Joe Biden that is reluctantly accepted by the House. That would probably save Boehner's fragile Speakership and contain Cantor's role.

I have been on the faculty at a major research center in the SUNY system for 25 years.  My university has been chronically starved for resources throughout my entire career.  Many of our departments are seriously understaffed and, as a result,  class sizes can be enormous.  Most of the younger faculty are woefully underpaid, but they consider themselves lucky to have tenured or tenure-track positions, given the abysmal job market for most Ph.D.s in academia.  As a testament to the profligacy of my university system that Just Thinking purports to know so much about, our own union recently negotiated a contract that includes furloughs (which cannot include any days that we teach) and pay cuts for all faculty and professional staff through increased contributions to medical and virtually no meaningful cost-of-living raises (which, by the way, have been relatively rare over the past 25 years).  I love my job and my university and I am grateful to be able to teach, mentor, and research for a living, but to impugn my colleagues -- who for the most part work exceedingly long hours, often seven days a week, throughout the year -- is beyond the pale.  Had Just Thinking thought to mention the unspeakable bloat in most university administrations, we might have found some room for agreement.

skeptic: 2 problems with your statement. 1) I don't work at UF (I moved away from Florida some time ago). 2) you seem to have used info from 'professional' colleges closely connected to industry, which drives up professor salaries (medicine, business, journalism, ag, etc) and which were explicitly not part of my post, and less relevant to this debate. The skills we're talking about here come from an education in the humanities and sciences. Liberal Arts and Sciences departments do give some or most Assoc Prof salaries in the low to mid-60s. Most humanities departments even have a few Assoc Profs with salaries in the low to mid-50s. And keep in mind that within the vast Florida state university system, these are the BEST paid professors. There are assoc. profs at other Florida universities who started in the high 40s and now only make in the 50s.

On the subject of high tuition....

The inflation rate has been under 3% for many years. Meanwhile, college tuitions have inflated at a much,much higher rate. It would be useful for economists to analyze the books of a number of universities and explain this mystery.

I have a suspicion that they would find that number of hours taught by professors has grossly diminished. Addition staff must be hired to compensate.

The starving academic is a myth. Salaries are high. Further, many professors run a de-facto personal consulting business by collaborating with industrial clients while the host university and students gets little benefit. It further dilutes their time for teaching.

Also, universities have added expensive facilities that are more appropriate for a country club than a place of higher learning.

There appear to be no constraints on tuition or its increases. Perhaps, this is because so much of it is funded ( directly or indirectly) by public entities. If loans were capped by statute, perhaps the spiral would cease and university would learn to live within their means.

For many conditions, placebos are scientifically shown to work well.

There are some "alternative" treatments that are not harmful to a patient or endangered species and that do let a patient feel more attuned to his body in a positive way, become calmer, and know that a practitioner cares about helping him feel better.

It shouldn't be surprising that this can make patients better than they would be without the treatment--and such treatments shouldn't be dismissed simply because they don't work by the same mechanism as a drug.

I really resent your implication that 'high school would not teach' these students.You say your administrators' solution is to 'lower the bar for college level work'. What makes you think that it's any different in high school?

We teachers as well as the school district itself are faced with relentless pressure to promote any warm body & to lower the bar. As teachers, we will be penalized by the state if we have 'too many' F's. In practice, anything more than 2 or 3 F's in your class is supposed to be a sign that *you* are the problem. The idea is that students are passive products who, with the right input, will output the correct data. So if they don't, the idea is that *you* haven't inputed the correct data. We are thus forced to lower the bar if we don't want to get fired.

Our society treats schools as customer commodities; if Johnny EARNS an F because he has done zero work, or has not come to school, his parents schedule a meeting with the principal to accuse *you* of being a bad teacher worthy of being fired. The principal just wants to keep the parents happy. Happy parents have passing students.

I have had students miss more than half the school year & not make up work whom I am instructed to pass. Schools are ranked by the state on graduation rate. How do you think they manage this?

Students learn early on that they can do nothing & still pass & be promoted. We also tell them that 'everyone' can go to college. And then we wonder why they do poorly in college?

Why does your institution accept these woefully  unprepared students?  You  must agree that if colleges and universities made it more difficult for students to enter students would perhaps rise to the occasion.  Instead, universities accept students and lure them with beautiful campuses that have nothing to do with scholarship.

Professors' hands are tied by the very low quality of students entering universities from the K-12 system. We would love to be the challenging, inspirational figures of Hollywood movies: but our extra time and effort doesn't even make a dent in their confusion and fear of the hard work of real learning, and the immense gap between what they 'know' how to do and what college-level work entails. Administrators' solution is to lower the bar for college-level work, and through various tools and metrics chide faculty into passing students who have not mastered any material or skills. What will employers say then about these 'fast-tracked' college graduates?

I teach college students at a well-known and well-respected state university, and the majority of them lack the tools to benefit from a college classroom. They are so far behind our minimum expectations in terms of writing, numeracy and critical thinking that instead of seeking to close the immense gap in their skills, they simply resent our "unreasonable demands" that they show progress in these areas.

We cannot take these victims of No Child Left Behind and Race to the Top, who view the world of higher learning and critical thinking with fear and resentment, and turn them into the citizens and employees this country needs. If anything, these students need MORE time, resources and attention, more remedial courses to fix what high school would not teach them, not fewer years in college.
